It is possible that there may be differences in brain activity between people of different religious traditions when they speak in tongues, as the experience can involve different beliefs, practices, and cultural norms.

For example, some religious traditions believe that speaking in tongues is a direct communication with God, while others view it as a form of meditation or a way to connect with their spirituality. This may result in differences in the neural pathways and brain activity associated with the experience.

However, further research is needed to explore this topic in more depth, as there is limited scientific evidence available on the neural correlates of speaking in tongues across different religious traditions.
